document.docAuthor: Gomes, Francisca Maiara Batista & Loeuille, Benoit
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic revision of Lychnocephalus (Lychnophorinae, Vernonieae, Asteraceae), an endemic genus of the Espinhaço Range, Minas Gerais, Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic revision of Lychnocephalus (Lychnophorinae, Vernonieae, Asteraceae), an endemic genus of the Espinhaço Range, Minas Gerais, Brazil

subSubSection.paragraph:
Lychnophora tomentosa (Mart. ex DC.) Schultz Bipontinus (1863: 369)
.

Type:— BRAZIL . Minas Gerais : in campis sterilibus, Serro Frio ,
25 May 1818
,
C.F.P. von Martius 1313 (515)
( holotype : M e ! [ M0029487 ]; isotypes: G-DC e ! [G00464243 (fragment)], P! [P02513407 (fragment)])
( Fig.6 G–H , Fig.9 A–H ).

Treelet , rarely shrubs , candelabriform, 1–1.2 m tall; poorly branched. Stems (0.6–) 1–2.3 cm diam., robust, dirty white, densely tomentose, glabrescent, surface tessellate. Leaves petiolate, petiole (0.5–) 2.5–2.7 cm , laxly disposed; leaf sheath amplexicaul, 0.9–1.9 × 1.1–1.8 cm , dirty white, abaxial surface densely tomentose, adaxial surface glabrous; blade elliptic, rarely ovate or obovate, (2.8–)4.7–13.2 × (0.9–) 4.5–5.6 cm , discolorous, venation pattern eucamptodromous, primary vein prominent abaxially, secondary veins not covered by indumentum, abaxial surface ochreous, tomentose to lanulose, adaxial surface dark-green, tomentose, glabrescent, flat, apex obtuse, base decurrent, rarely rounded. Third-order syncephalium (1.1–) 2–4.2 cm tall, (1.2–) 2–6 cm diam., composed of 3–6 second-order syncephalia, spherical, solitary or sometimes 2–3 grouped, terminal or axillary, covered by tomentose indumentum, pedunculate, peduncle (3–) 12.2–20 cm long; tertiary bracts 2.3–4.6 × 1.2–2.7 cm , lanceolate; secondary bracts 1.1–2.1 × (0.6–) 1–1.7 cm , lanceolate to deltoid. Capitula (10–)20–120, subinvolucral bracts 0.9–1.1 × 0.5–1 cm , deltoid; involucre campanulate, (0.6–) 0.8–10 mm tall × 3.1–4.8 mm diam.; phyllaries 3 or 4-seriate, outer series shorter than inner series, oblong, apex obtuse, sometimes rounded, glabrous, margin entire, outer phyllaries 4–7.1 × 1–3.2 mm , inner phyllaries 6.2–11.1 × 1.5–2.2 mm ; receptacle fimbrillate. Florets (4)–12–15 per capitulum, corolla deeply 5– lobed, purple, 0.8–1.4 cm long, corolla tube 0.7–1.1 cm × 0.2–0.5 cm , corolla lobes 2.8–4 × 0.4–0.8 mm , pubescent; anthers 3.5–4.8 × 0.1–0.2 mm , purple; style shaft 0.7–13 mm long, purple, glabrous throughout except for pubescent upper 1.5–1.8 mm beneath style arms, style arms 1.5–3 mm long. Cypselae cylindrical, 3.5–4.1 × 0.5–1 mm , brown; pappus setae biseriate, outer series shorter than inner series, stramineous, outer series 1.1–1.3 mm long, apex erose, inner series 5–7 mm long.
Distribution and habitat: — Brazil ( Minas Gerais , Diamantina Plateau and Serra do Cipó). Campo rupestre , occurring on sandy soils, at elevations between 1,000 and 1,360 m ( Fig. 8 ).
Phenology: —Specimens found with florets and fruits between February and July.
Etymology: —The epithet refers to the indumentum covering branches and abaxial surface of leaves.

Informal conservation status: —The species is considered Endangered (EOO = 7.311, 254 km 2 ; AOO = 8.8000 km 2 ) according to criteria B1ab(i,iv,v) + B2ab(i,iv,v) ( Fernandez et al 2020 ).
Lychnocephalus tomentosus
has recorded occurrence within Protected Areas: Environmental Protection Area (EPA) Serra Talhada, State Park (SP) Biribiri, EPA Morro da Pedreira, National Park (NP) Serra do Cipó and NP Sempre Vivas. However, the species is threatened by factors like urbanization, agriculture, road grid expansion, introduction of exotic species and tourism ( Fernandes & Barbosa 2013 ).

Taxonomic Notes: —This is the most common species of the genus. It is easily recognized by the combination of robust branches, densely tomentose indumentum, and petiolate leaves. The other species displaying petiolate leaves is
L. mellobarretoi
. Other differences are discussed above. Some populations of
L. tomentosus
found in the National Park Sempre Vivas (Diamantina Plateau) have slender branches and smaller syncephalia, making those specimens more similar to
L. mellobarretoi
, but they are still clearly distinguished by the habit (treelet vs. shrub) and outer pappus series (longer than 1 mm vs. shorter than 0.5 mm ). Additionally, some individuals from these populations have subsessile leaves. Nevertheless, these morphological variations are uncommon and insufficient to justify a distinct formal taxonomic status.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9.
Lychnocephalus tomentosus
. A. Flowering branch. B. Leaf adaxial surface. C. Leaf abaxial surface. D. Syncephalium. E. Capitulum. F. Outer phyllary and inner phyllary. G. Corolla, androecium, and style. H. Cypsela.
